The British government is pledging yet again to stop European Union migrants from claiming benefits after EU officials slapped down the plans last year. [Former Prime Minister David Cameron made the promise a key part of his demands while attempting to renegotiate the terms of Britainâ€™s EU membership. However, other EU leaders would only agree to a temporary compromise, forcing Mr Cameron into an embarrassing climb down and helping fuel the Brexit vote.  Now his successor Theresa May is looking at resurrecting the policy and bringing EU migrants in line with migrants from elsewhere in the world. The Times reports that the government is considering the move along with a series of other decisions over the future of Britainâ€™s immigration system after Brexit. In February last year, government data showed the UK has paid over Â£1 billion in welfare payments to unemployed EU migrants. Figures showed that in   alone, British taxpayers paid Â£886million for unemployed EU migrants living in the UK, and a further Â£814 million for EU migrants in work. Now the government is deciding whether to finally honour David Cameronâ€™s pledge of ending these benefits, although they have so far refused to commit. The report comes as the government continues to give mixed signals over its Brexit strategy. David Davis, the Brexit minister, has hinted he would not like to see business affected by curbs on   immigration, indicating at various times that Britain could stay in leave the Single Market. Chancellor Philip Hammond has also called for a â€œbusiness friendlyâ€ Brexit, although has declined to go into details. However, Theresa May is determined to appear tough on immigration. In her speech to the Conservative Party conference in October, the Prime Minister said: â€œWe are not leaving the European Union to give up control over immigration again. â€œWe are leaving to be a fully sovereign and independent country  â€”   and that deal is going to have to work for Britain. â€

Suspected cartel gunmen killed another   journalist. This year, reporters exposing drug cartels and their ties to Mexican politicians have become targets with five murders taking place in 2017. Valdez was driving a red Toyota Corolla along a city street in Culiacan, Sinaloa, when unidentified gunmen shot him, Rio Doce reported. Mexicoâ€™s Network of Journalists from the Northeast expressed their condemnation and demanded that Mexicoâ€™s government stop turning a blind eye to the escalating violence.  â€œWe come once again and as many times as necessary to harshly demand that authorities carry out their duty of protecting citizens from criminals and punish criminals according to the Rule of Law,â€ a prepared statement from the network revealed. WASHINGTON  â€”   President Trump ordered a cruise missile strike against a Syrian regime military airbase, in response to a chemical weapons attack carried out by the regime earlier this week. [At 8:40 p. m. EDT, the U. S. launched 59 Tomahawk land attack missiles at the Shayrat Airfield located in the Homs Governorate in Western Syria, according to Pentagon officials. The strike lasted minutes.  â€œThis was in response to the Syrian chemical weapons attack April 4th in Khan Sheikhoun  â€¦     That attack killed and injured hundreds of innocent Syrian people, including women and children,â€ said Pentagon spokesman Navy Capt. Jeff Davis. â€œThe strikes were intended to deter the regime from using chemical weapons again,â€ he said. The missiles were launched from U. S. destroyers USS Porter and Ross, which were in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea at the time, he said. The missiles hit aircraft, hardened aircraft shelters, petroleum and logistical storage areas, ammunition supply bunkers, air defense systems and radars, he said. Davis said the U. S. military took care to avoid any human casualties. It notified Russia  â€”   and â€œmany countriesâ€  â€”   of the planned strikes ahead of time. There were Russian troops at the airbase, although itâ€™ is not clear if they were still there during the strikes. Davis said the U. S. struck an area where Russian and Syrian troops were not located. â€œIn this case in particular, every precaution was taken to execute these strikes with minimal risk to personnel at the airfield,â€ Davis said. The strike was aimed at deterring another chemical weapons attack by the regime. The airbase was the same one the regime used to carry out the chemical weapons attack, Davis said. The U. S. military said it tracked the two aircraft that the regime used to conduct the attacks. The airbase also housed one of Syriaâ€™s main chemical weapons storage facility prior to 2013, he said. Trump had hinted on Wednesday during a Rose Garden briefing with the King of Jordan that he would take action against the regime. He said the attack had crossed â€œmany, many lines, beyond a red line  â€”   many, many lines. â€ â€œThat attack on children yesterday had a big impact on me. Big impact,â€ Trump had said. â€œThat was a horrible, horrible thing, and Iâ€™ve been watching it and seeing it, and it doesnâ€™t get any worse than that. â€ Trump reportedly spoke with lawmakers before the strike. Sen. Rand Paul ( ) called on the president to come to Congress to seek congressional authorization for military action in Syria. â€œWhile we all condemn the atrocities in Syria, the US was not attacked,â€ he said in a statement. â€œThe President needs congressional authorization for military action and I call on him to come to Congress for a proper debate on our role. Our prior interventions in this region have done nothing to make us safer and Syria will be no different. â€ Sen. Ted Cruz ( ) called Syrian President Bashar   a â€œmonsterâ€ and a â€œpuppet of Russia and Iranâ€ but said he looked forward to the president â€œmaking the case to Congress and the American peopleâ€ in the days ahead. Meanwhile, Republican and Democratic defense hawks praised the airstrikes. â€œUnlike the previous administration, President Trump confronted a pivotal moment in Syria and took action,â€ said Sens. John McCain ( ) and Lindsey Graham ( ). â€œI think it was an important step,â€ Sen. Marco Rubio ( ) said on CNN. â€œThis was not some symbolic measure. â€ â€œI support the adminâ€™s strike on the air base that launched the chemical attack. I hope this teaches Assad not to use chemical weapons again,â€ said Sen. Bill Nelson ( ). In a statement, President Trump explained the urgency behind the strikes: My fellow Americans, on Tuesday, Syrian dictator Bashar   launched a horrible chemical weapons attack on innocent civilians. Using a deadly nerve agent, Assad choked out the lives of helpless men, women and children. It was a slow and brutal death for so many, even beautiful babies were cruelly murdered in this very barbaric attack. No child of God should ever suffer such horror. Tonight, I ordered a targeted military strike on the airfield in Syria from where a chemical attack was launched. It is in the vital, national security interest of the United States to prevent and deter the spread and use of deadly chemical weapons. There can be no dispute that Syria used banned chemical weapons, violated its obligations under the chemical weapons convention and ignored the urging of the U. N. Security Council. Years of previous attempts at changing Assadâ€™s behavior have all failed, and failed very dramatically. As a result, the refugee crisis continues to deepen and the region continues to destabilize, threatening the United States and its allies. Tonight I call on all civilized nations to join us in seeking to end the slaughter and bloodshed in Syria and also to end terrorism of all kinds and all types. We ask for Godâ€™s wisdom as we face the challenge of our very troubled world. We pray for the lives of the wounded and for the souls of those who have passed and we hope that as long as America stands for justice, that peace and harmony will, in the end, prevail. Good night and God bless America and the entire world. Thank you.

China will â€œmost likelyâ€ try to expand its military footprint in countries that share Beijingâ€™s strategic interests and have long been considered its ally, namely Pakistan, as the communist country increases its â€œpower projection into the Indian Ocean,â€ reports the Pentagon in an annual report to the U. S. Congress. [In the   report issued Tuesday, the U. S. Department of Defense (DoD) warns under a subsection titled â€œMilitary Cooperationâ€:  As Chinaâ€™s regional and international interests grow more complex, the PLAâ€™s [Peopleâ€™s Liberation Army] international engagement will continue to expand, especially in the areas of PKO [peacekeeping operations] counterpiracy,   [humanitarian   relief, counterterrorism, and joint exercises. The Pentagon later adds that â€œChina most likely will seek to establish additional military bases in countries with which it has a longstanding friendly relationship and similar strategic interests, such as Pakistan, and in which there is a precedent for hosting foreign militaries. â€ In August 2016, Beijing reached a military counterterrorism pact with Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Tajikistan. Beijing believes terrorism, primarily stemming from Pakistan and, to a lesser extent,   Afghanistan, poses a threat to Chinaâ€™s One Belt, One Road (OBOR) initiative, known as the 21st Century Silk Road project. As of 2015, China was the globeâ€™s   arms supplier, with Pakistan being one of its top customers. Pakistan receives more weapons from China than any other country. â€œChina is one of only a few global suppliers of such [armed unmanned aerial vehicles  â€”   UAV] equipment and faces little competition for sales to the Middle East and North Africa,â€ notes the Pentagon. â€œThis likely will result in the Middle East and North Africa surpassing   Africa as Chinaâ€™s second largest arms export market. â€ Pakistan and China, which consider India to be their regional foe, have agreed on the construction of the estimated $55 billion   Economic Corridor (CPEC) a component of Beijingâ€™s nearly $1 trillion modern Silk Road, officially known as Chinese President Xi Jinpingâ€™s OBOR initiative. It appears China is using its OBOR project as justification to expand its military footprint to many of the 60 countries in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa that are involved in the ambitious project. Leaked documents recently obtained by Pakistanâ€™s DAWN purportedly revealed that Beijing is planning to use CPEC to suppress Islamic terrorism, diversity, and democracy in its   ally. It appears China is seeking to expand its military might beyond neighboring Pakistan and Afghanistan across various other countries. â€œChinaâ€™s overseas military basing may be constrained by the willingness of countries to support a PLA [Peopleâ€™s Liberation Army] presence in one of their ports,â€ it adds. Pakistan, the top recipient of Chinese weapons as well as other military assistance and foreign aid, is already collaborating with Beijingâ€™s military ambitions. With Pakistanâ€™s blessing, China has deployed naval ships to the Singapore   Gwadar Sea Port to safeguard the port and trade under the   Economic Corridor. From Gwadar port, Chinaâ€™s area of operation would include a region from the Arabian Sea to the African coast, and, of course, the Gulf would be its area of operation. India is opposed to Chinaâ€™s plan to set up military bases within its periphery. Nevertheless, China has already begun to establish military bases in the Indian Ocean, namely Djibouti and in the Gwadar port in Pakistanâ€™s Balochistan province. As has been Beijingâ€™s policy for a long time, Chinaâ€™s goal is to isolate India. In the Indian Ocean, China intends to construct a military base network that would include Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, the Seychelles, and Djibouti, among others. The Pentagon reports: In May 2016, a large PLAN [PLA Navy] task force conducted an extensive deployment through the South China Sea, eastern Indian Ocean, and Western Pacific Ocean. The force conducted island assault training in the Spratly Islands and maritime interdiction training in the Indian Ocean before linking up to conduct an   exercise in the Philippine Sea. DoD also notes: China also continued to send submarines to the Indian Ocean, ostensibly in support of its counterpiracy patrols. In May 2016, a   powered attack submarine conducted a port call in Karachi, Pakistan, during a visit by the PLAN Commander, marking Chinaâ€™s first port call in South Asia by a nuclear submarine. These submarine patrols demonstrate the PLANâ€™s emerging capability both to protect Chinaâ€™s SLOCs [sea lines of communication] and to increase Chinaâ€™s power projection into the Indian Ocean. In what seems to be a pushback to Chinaâ€™s ambitious OBOR project, India and Japan are embarking upon multiple infrastructure projects across Africa, Iran, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia. Last month, the Economic Times noted, â€œIndia has conspicuously stayed away from the   New Silk Road, launched with much fanfare by Chinese President Xi Jinping on Sunday, because of strategic and security concerns. â€ The   Economic Corridor is expected to run through the disputed   Kashmir (POK) a move that will certainly cause tension with India since New Delhi claims ownership of the region. China considers the growing Islamic terrorism threat it is facing to stem from Pakistan and to a lesser extent Afghanistan, according to the U. S.  Economic and Security Review Commission. Beijing and Kabul have already signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to integrate Afghanistan into the 21st Century Silk Road.   Kashmir and Afghanistan border Chinaâ€™s autonomous and largest Xinjiang province, home to the countryâ€™s Muslim Uighur minority.

Greg Zimmerman, an environmental activist, was scrolling through the website of a coal industry association when he came across a presentation that startled him: â€œSurvival Is Victory: Lessons From the Tobacco Wars. â€ What surprised Mr. Zimmerman, the deputy policy director at the Center for Western Priorities, a conservation advocacy organization based in Denver, was that the coal industry was, at least in this presentation, deliberately drawing a comparison between itself and the tobacco companies. That is more typically the argument of environmentalists, who often compare fossil fuel companies to the tobacco industry. They note that the tobacco giants for many years funded   science and advocacy groups to spread doubt about risks of smoking. Fossil fuel companies, they argue, have engaged in similar efforts, and investigations by state attorneys general have focused on the tactics of Exxon Mobil, which has funded groups that deny the scientific evidence that human activity has increased global warming. Fossil fuel companies and their allies generally ridicule the comparison to tobacco. But here was an internal document from the industry that, as Mr. Zimmerman said, â€œhas sort of done our job for us. â€ Others have taken note of it as well. After reviewing the presentation, shared with him by a reporter, the state attorney general leading the investigation of Exxon Mobil, Eric T. Schneiderman of New York, called it important. â€œThis is just the latest example of the fossil fuel industry explicitly adopting the Big Tobacco playbook,â€ he said. Mr. Schneiderman reached a settlement last year with Peabody Energy, the giant coal company, after finding that it had not properly disclosed to the public and its shareholders the risks of climate change and regulation to its business  â€”   an investigation similar to Mr. Schneidermanâ€™s efforts to determine whether Exxon Mobil had committed fraud in its public statements about climate change. The   â€œSurvival Is Victoryâ€ presentation was given a year ago at the convention and annual meeting of the Rocky Mountain Coal Mining Institute, an industry group representing coal interests in Western states. The author of the presentation, Richard Reavey, is the vice president for government and public affairs at Cloud Peak Energy, a mining company based in Wyoming. From 1990 to 2007, Mr. Reavey served as an executive with Philip Morris International, working in communications and government affairs. The slides did not acknowledge the scientific consensus on climate change, but stated that public opinion had shifted so substantially that the question was moot. â€œWe need to get out of the binary debate on climate change,â€ one slide read. â€œRight, but dead, is not a victory. â€ The presentation called on the industry to prepare for more stringent regulation, and to build a better future for the industry and its workers by pushing for more research into technology that can capture carbon dioxide from smokestacks, which could extend the use of coal. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has recognized a possible role for carbon capture in meeting global goals for limiting carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere, but commercial development of the technology has proved somewhat troublesome. Mr. Reavey noted that the tobacco industry had settled lawsuits with 48 states in 1998 and agreed to regulation by the Food and Drug Administration. The deal looked to some like the â€œEnd of Days,â€ he wrote in a slide, but â€œa much more heavily regulated tobacco industry is viable and profitable. â€ Like so many elements of climate change, coal is a polarizing issue for political parties. The 2016 Republican Party platform strongly supports a continued role for coal, referring to it as â€œan abundant, clean, affordable, reliable domestic energy resource,â€ and calls for killing the Obama administrationâ€™s Clean Power Plan, which would continue the process of reducing dependence on coal for producing energy. Hillary Clinton, the Democratic candidate for president, has promised to â€œdefend and implementâ€ the Clean Power Plan while providing economic opportunities in coal communities affected by it. For its part, Exxon Mobil has stated that it now accepts the validity of climate science and favors a carbon tax it also says that since the   it has not funded groups that play down scientific evidence of the human role in global warming. In an interview, Mr. Reavey, who developed the slide presentation, said it simply recognized the â€œpolitical realityâ€ that Americans accepted climate science in increasing numbers. And while the presentation compared coal and tobacco, the two industries are â€œcompletely different,â€ he added. â€œAt the end of the day, energy is something that we, as a society, require. Tobacco is not. â€ But a string of recent bankruptcy filings by coal companies has shown the extensive support from the industry for groups that deny the scientific validity of climate change and oppose environmental regulations. Mr. Reavey said that his company, Cloud Peak, â€œhas never fought climate change  â€”   never fought it, never denied it or funded anyone who does. â€ The executive director of the industry group, Judy Colgan, recalled that Mr. Reaveyâ€™s presentation delivered a message the audience was ready to hear. The industry, she said, has recognized that the time for arguing over climate science has passed. â€œWe can fight this climate debate all we want to itâ€™s not going to help the industry survive,â€ she said, adding that very few people are going to change their minds. Instead, she added, developing carbon capture should be the top priority. Naomi Oreskes, a historian who has compared the science and public relations of the tobacco and fossil fuel industries, said that while much of the investigative attention in the past year has focused on Exxon Mobil, the coal industry presentation â€œis a reminder that this is a much more complicated story than just Exxon Mobil. â€ Money the coal industry spent on attacking climate science might have been invested to develop effective carbon capture technology, she said. â€œThat, to me, is a little bit heartbreaking,â€ she added. â€œNow I think, â€˜Guys, thatâ€™s a day late and a dollar short. â€™â€

If the weather hadnâ€™t been so foul, the most dramatic moment of Tiffany Malloryâ€™s wedding to Jerrell Moore would never have happened. â€œIt had been pouring, and then it stopped raining but turned cold and windy right as we started the ceremony,â€ said Mrs. Mallory Moore, who was married April 2 before 140 guests on the back lawn of the Mint Museum in Charlotte, N. C. Just as she arrived through the squall to meet her groom at the altar, a gust blew her veil into the sky. â€œIt went flying, right off my head,â€ she said. â€œBut Iâ€™m over six feet tall, so people thought it looked very glamorous. â€ During a very wet April and May on the East Coast, many couples learned the hard way that a perfect (or at least nearly perfect) wedding does not require perfect weather. â€œDid my guests get wet? Yes, kind of,â€ said Minoo Fadaifard Wade, who married John Wade in a drizzle on May 21 at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in front of a crowd of 82. â€œIt was chilly, too. But nobody complained. Everybody made the best of it. We were all lighthearted. â€ Should rain clouds threaten your wedding, here are some tips on how to salvage that perfect day, provided by couples who have managed to do just that. Rain was expected on May 22, the day Jill Jacinto, 30, was to marry Sander van den Bergh, 31, on the outdoor terrace of Battery Gardens, a New York restaurant. But she held out hope that the day would clear by the ceremonyâ€™s 4:30 p. m. start time. â€œI gave up on checking weather. com the night before and assumed an indoor ceremony was in our future and out of our hands,â€ said Ms. Jacinto, an associate director at an investment firm. â€œBut then 30 minutes before the start time, the sun came out. â€ The couple was able to swiftly switch from their Plan B  â€”   an   sheltered space  â€”   to the patio, their Plan A. â€œWe ended up with a gorgeous ceremony,â€ Ms. Jacinto said. â€œBut we were ready for whatever happened. â€ At Mariana Rodrigues and David Rothschildâ€™s May 21 wedding at Cherry Hill in Central Park, rain began falling as guests boarded   buses bound for a reception at the NoMad Hotel. â€œThe bus driver was really kind and offered everyone on the upper deck ponchos, but I was pretty upset,â€ said Mrs. Rothschild, 32, a former financial executive. â€œThen I was upset with myself for being upset, and David reminded me that that was absolutely warranted, that I was allowed to have that moment. â€ She did not let the moment last, though. â€œI realized it wasnâ€™t perfect but it was a great celebration,â€ she said. â€œYou have to remember that the weather is out of your control, and just enjoy yourself. â€ Erin McGrail and Elliot Fleming invited 150 guests to their June 2014 wedding under a stately oak tree at the Destrehan Plantation, just outside New Orleans. Thirty minutes before the ceremony, the sky turned black. â€œThen it just started pouring torrentially in that typical New Orleans way,â€ Mrs. Fleming, 28, said. Instead of panicking as she watched friends and family run for shelter at a gift shop, she played it cool. â€œAt first I took it badly,â€ Mrs. Fleming said. â€œThen I saw how upset my mom was. So I said to myself, â€˜Stay calm, we can figure this out. â€™â€ The wedding was moved to the reception site nearby, where guests were seated at decorated tables. â€œBut it didnâ€™t matter: At that point I had just accepted it for what it was,â€ said Mrs. Fleming, who works in purchasing at the Audubon Zoo in New Orleans. Looking back, she added, she wouldnâ€™t change a thing. â€œYour state of mind is going to determine your guestsâ€™ state of mind,â€ said Constantino Khalaf. Mr. Khalaf, 36, married David Khalaf, 38, on May 14 in Cathedral Park in Portland, Ore. the coupleâ€™s hometown, under drizzly skies with the occasional hard rain. There was no shelter for their 65 guests. â€œWe warned people far in advance to bring their umbrellas and raincoats, because we knew getting married in May in Portland was like playing Russian roulette with the weather,â€ said David Khalaf, who runs the Christian website Modern Kinship with his husband. Then they made the best of it. During the reception, held at the wedding site, â€œWe all huddled together to stay warm, and we danced in the rain,â€ he said. â€œIf youâ€™re just like, â€˜Hey, this is a beautiful occasion, letâ€™s dance in the rain,â€™ everybody is going to pick up on that,â€ â€œThe first advice I would give is: Ask all your vendors what their rain policies are, and read the contracts closely,â€ said Mrs. Mallory Moore, the bride whose veil wouldnâ€™t stay put and who is also an assistant United States attorney with the Western District of North Carolina. That includes contracts with musicians. â€œSome live musicians who play string instruments wonâ€™t play in dampness,â€ she said. â€œWe had a trio of horn players, so it worked out for us. But it might not have if we had a violinist. â€ She also was not sure how her florist would handle broken vases several were smashed in the storm. The couple was not charged. â€œBut you really have to pay attention to that stuff,â€ Mrs. Mallory Moore said. Rachel Bowie felt personally responsible when the rain started coming down on May 13 at Janeâ€™s Carousel in Brooklyn, where 99 guests had gathered to watch her and Matthew Dorville get married. â€œIt was Friday the 13th. We sort of asked for it,â€ she said. But she was glad she remembered a tip from her photographer: buy a lot of clear umbrellas. â€œThey donâ€™t cast a shadow on your face,â€ said Mrs. Bowie, 33, an editor who lives in Brooklyn. If she had to do it over again, she would have asked a friend to pack galoshes for her, too. â€œRight before I walked down the aisle my shoes were so wet I was slipping in them. I had been jumping through those gross, deceptively deep New York City puddles. â€ Hurricane Irene was an uninvited guest at the August 2011 wedding of Jacqueline Shea and Matthew Bailey of Eatontown, N. J. When the bride was getting her nails done in preparation for the rehearsal dinner, an evacuation was ordered for an area that included the wedding site on the beach near Asbury Park.â€™ â€â€œI was in denial, like, this is not happening,â€ said Mrs. Bailey, 35, a teacher of the deaf. The couple married that night at a local restaurant. Flowers were assembled from Trader Joeâ€™s, and the brideâ€™s mother bought a sheet cake from ShopRite.â€ â€™Then, vendors refused to refund deposits for the wedding. A year later, the couple appeared on Anderson Cooperâ€™s   talk show, â€œAnderson,â€ ostensibly to warn other couples about the need to buy wedding insurance. Instead, Mr. Cooper announced that the show was giving them a wedding redo, including a reception at the Wilshire Grand Hotel in West Orange, N. J. and a trip to the Caribbean island of St. Lucia, to renew their vows on the beach. The Baileys now have two children, ages 1 and 2Â½, and more perspective on   disasters. â€œI think what happened to us is sort of like a precursor to what everybody finds out once theyâ€™re married,â€ Mrs. Bailey said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s that there are ups and there are downs in married life, sometimes big ones. What you do is you make the most of it, no matter what. â€

The former papal spokesman has denied rumors that Pope Benedict XVI resigned under â€œtremendous pressures,â€ including from the Obama administration, asserting rather that he did so under his own volition. [In response to recent statements by Italian Archbishop Luigi Negri that suggested Benedict had resigned under significant duress, Father Federico Lombardi (pictured) said Thursday that the Pope Emeritus must be taken at his word when he said he had stepped down â€œin full freedom and responsibility. â€  â€œThere is no mystery to be revealed,â€ Lombardi said. â€œBenedict XVI is a man who put the truth first. How can someone so blatantly contradict what he said and then solemnly reaffirmed?â€ In statements earlier this week, Archbishop Negri claimed that the Obama administration may have been complicit in the â€œtremendous pressuresâ€ that led the former pope to resign in 2013. It is â€œno coincidenceâ€ that some Catholic groups â€œhave asked President Trump to open a commission of inquiry to investigate whether the administration of Barack Obama exerted pressure on Benedict,â€ Negri said in an interview Monday, citing revelations by Wikileaks regarding efforts by the Democratic Party to influence the Catholic Church in the United States. Father Lombardi, who was papal spokesman during the Benedict years, noted that the former pontiff offered a substantially different account of his resignation from the one offered by Negri, and he did so â€œpublicly before the cardinals gathered in Consistory and the worldâ€ and again in an interview book with Peter Seewald titled Last Testament. According to Father Lombardi, Negriâ€™s comments have provoked questions and â€œunnecessary confusion. â€ Negri, who claims to be Benedictâ€™s â€œfriend,â€ offers an odd demonstration of friendship in â€œtriumphantlyâ€ contradicting what his friend has said, Lombardi observes. â€œI do not think it is necessary to think of terrible pressures from overseas,â€ Lombardi states. â€œWe can easily think that his was a very wise and sensible decision, before God and before men. â€ â€œI believe that several of his successors will be grateful,â€ he said. PARIS  â€”   First it was the Netherlands. After President Trump vowed to put â€œAmerican first,â€ a Dutch television show made a satirical case for why the president should consider its country second. Now, the race for   has spread. Belgium, Germany, Denmark, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal and Switzerland have all joined in with videos that capture the presidentâ€™s trademark bombast, demonstrating a rare case of European unity through satire  â€”   and  . In the Dutch video, a     runs through a list of the countryâ€™s hallmarks and traditions that may pique Mr. Trumpâ€™s interest: the language, the tax code, the windmills and Black Pete, a contentious Christmas tradition in which Dutch people wear blackface. (â€œItâ€™s the most offensive, the most racist thing youâ€™ve ever seen,â€ the voice says. It adds: â€œYouâ€™ll love it. Itâ€™s great. â€) Arjen Lubach, a Dutch   host whose show, â€œZondag met Lubachâ€ (â€œSunday With Lubachâ€) made the video that started the trend, said, â€œBecause we realize itâ€™s better for us to get along, we decided to introduce our tiny country to him in a way that will probably appeal to him the most. â€ The     on this video belongs to a   American comedian named Greg Shapiro. â€œIâ€™ve been working on the imitation for a while,â€ Mr. Shapiro said in a phone interview on Sunday from Paris. All it takes, he said, is repeating Mr. Trumpâ€™s interviews or tweets verbatim. â€œThereâ€™s hardly any heightening necessary,â€ he said. After the video went viral, Mr. Shapiro said, â€œit was nice having family from America send me these clips saying, â€˜Oh, this is like Dutch and Trump.â€™ And Iâ€™d say, â€˜Yeah, thatâ€™s my voice.â€™ My mom did recognize it. â€ Mr. Shapiro, 48, has seen a bump on his YouTube channel, where he offers lessons in Trump impressions on his â€œUnited States of Europeâ€ show and posted a spoof news conference on Monday, in which he impersonates the president. Germanyâ€™s video pleads its case  â€”   and expresses indignation that the Netherlands beat it to the idea. Its video lists Oktoberfest, the countryâ€™s experience with walls and Hitler, who, the video notes, â€œmade Germany great again. â€ â€œGermany wants to be second,â€ Jan BÃ¶hmermann, host of the talk show â€œNeo Magazin Royale,â€ said in the video. â€œBecause we are strong, we are big, and who  â€”   if not us  â€”   deserves a third chance?â€ (Last year, Mr. BÃ¶hmermannâ€™s satire of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan caused an international incident.) What did the Swiss think Mr. Trump would like about their country? The video championed the nationâ€™s mountains (itâ€™s not flat like the Netherlands) its nonmembership in the European Union and its cleanliness. It also said Mr. Trump, who was caught on video boasting about sexual assault, might appreciate the countryâ€™s history on womenâ€™s rights. â€œWe also love to treat our women badly,â€ the Trump impersonator in its video said. â€œLove it. We didnâ€™t let them vote until 1971. In some places, even until 1990. â€ It added: â€œYou love gold? We love gold. During World War II, the Jews gave it to us for safekeeping. They never returned  â€”   so strange  â€”   so we melted it, like fondue, our national dish. â€ Portugalâ€™s video noted that Portuguese has an untranslatable word, â€œsaudade,â€ a combination of longing and nostalgia. â€œWe can assure you that â€˜saudadeâ€™ is something that billions of people are feeling right now about Barack Obama. â€ It also jokes that its prime minister, AntÃ³nio Costa, like Mr. Trump, came to power without winning the popular vote. â€œIf you have any problems with Putin  â€”   which you will  â€”   immediately call AntÃ³nio Costa,â€ it said. Belgium extended an olive branch to Mr. Trump in its video, agreeing with his comments last March that its capital, Brussels, was a â€œhellhole,â€ but urging him to check out the   north of the country. (It dismissed the French speaking south as â€œthe Mexicans of Belgiumâ€ and told him to steer clear.) Denmarkâ€™s video, broadcast by the talk show â€œNatholdetâ€ (â€œThe Nightshiftâ€) explained the difference between Danes and danishes, and cited Hans Christian Andersen, creator of beloved fairy tales, as a point in the countryâ€™s favor. â€œYou have the Statue of Liberty, we have the Little Mermaid,â€ the videoâ€™s Trump impersonator said. â€œBut donâ€™t let the name fool you, O. K.? The Little Mermaid is actually pretty huge. â€ In its video, Luxembourg boasted, â€œWe have money, a lot of money,â€ adding: â€œAnd you know what, Mr. President? You donâ€™t even have to pay taxes. None. Zero. Nada. Promise. â€ Lithuania, a small Baltic country and NATO member that has been rattled by Mr. Trumpâ€™s fondness for Russia, attempted to win him over with its fast internet speed. â€œJust imagine how fast you can tweet when you have the fastest internet?â€ The video added that the Lithuanian president is a woman. â€œShe probably rigged the election,â€ the   said.

LONDON  â€”   The actor Samuel L. Jackson has sidled into a debate about the roles for black actors on both sides of the Atlantic. In an interview with the radio station Hot 97 posted online on Monday, Mr. Jackson questioned the casting of the black British actor Daniel Kaluuya in the   film â€œGet Out,â€ about a black Americanâ€™s encounter with his white girlfriendâ€™s creepy family. Mr. Jackson suggested that â€œan American brotherâ€ might have brought a deeper perspective to the role, and suggested that black Britons had endured less racism than  . He noted that British actors often secured American roles because they are less well known and therefore paid less, and because many of them are valued for their classical training. Jordan Peele, the writer and director of â€œGet Out,â€ has acknowledged that he was hesitant to cast a British actor, given that the film focuses on the   experience. Mr. Jackson said on Wednesday that his intention had been to comment on Hollywood, not to â€œslamâ€ Mr. Kaluuya. And while his comments have been criticized by many black commentators  â€”   American and British  â€”   some British performers do seem to find it easier to get roles in the United States than at home. Here is what some British minority actors who have worked in the United States have said about the issue. Mr. Boyega, who is from South London, plays Finn in â€œStar Wars: The Force Awakens. â€ While the role is not American per se, given that the film unfolds in a distant galaxy, Finn speaks with an entirely convincing American accent. In a tweet on Tuesday, Mr. Boyega appeared to dismiss Mr. Jacksonâ€™s comments: â€œBlack brits vs African American,â€ he wrote, saying that the conflict was â€œstupidâ€ and one â€œwe donâ€™t have time for. â€ Itâ€™s not just black British actors who have found success in the United States. Mr. Ahmed, a British actor of Pakistani descent, has slipped into several American roles, including the lead character, Nasir, on HBOâ€™s series â€œThe Night Of,â€ and a philandering surfing instructor on â€œGirls,â€ also on HBO. He recently addressed Parliament about a lack and misrepresentation of minority characters in the arts, suggesting that the problem might even be driving young Britons toward extremist beliefs. â€œWe end up going to America to find work,â€ Mr. Ahmed said. â€œI meet with producers and directors here and they say, â€˜We donâ€™t have anything for you all our stories are set in Cornwall in the 1600s. â€™â€ Ms. Harris, who plays Paula, the   mother of the lead character, Chiron, in the   â€œMoonlight,â€ is from London. She had to film her scenes in the movie in just three days, because of issues securing a visa to the United States. â€œI definitely think that for my career to have continued I definitely had to go to America, and Iâ€™m really glad that I did there is just a lot more material,â€ Ms. Harris told reporters at the premiere of â€œMoonlightâ€ at the London Film Festival last year. Mr. Ejiofor portrayed Solomon Northup, a free   who was abducted and enslaved in the   century. He has made an acting career with a foot on both sides of the Atlantic. In a 2015 interview with Time Out, he seemed to shy from discussion of the role race had played in his career, but suggested that the notable success that British actors of all races have enjoyed in the United States may have to do with different career expectations. â€œWe all wanted to be theater actors,â€ he said of his fellow Britons. â€œItâ€™s less glamorous much more about the work. You have to get on with it. You have to know when somethingâ€™s not working. And you have to hone your craft. Maybe that gives us an advantage. â€ Mr. Oyelowo, who is based in the United States, toiled in smaller roles before landing the part of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 2014   drama â€œSelma. â€ In a speech on diversity in London last year, Mr. Oyelowo pleaded with members of the British film industry to create more roles for minorities in Britain, noting that many actors felt obliged to move to the United States. â€œPlease stop this talent drain,â€ he said. â€œYou have to change the demographics of the people who are making these decisions. â€ Mr. Elba grew up in London and broke into the American market with his starring role as the Baltimore drug lord Stringer Bell on HBOâ€™s â€œThe Wire. â€ In an address to Parliament last year, Mr. Elba called on media representatives to make more room for minorities. â€œThe Britain I come from is the most successful, diverse, multicultural country on Earth,â€ Mr. Elba said. â€œBut hereâ€™s my point: You wouldnâ€™t know it if you turned on the TV. â€ Sophie Okonedo described herself as a Jewish, Nigerian Brit when accepting her 2014 Tony Award for playing the   character Ruth Winger in â€œA Raisin in the Sunâ€ on Broadway. She told The Guardian in 2014 that she saw far more opportunities for roles in the United States than in Britain. â€œI do notice that  â€”   over the last year  â€”   Iâ€™ve had maybe two scripts from England and tens and tens from America,â€ she said. â€œThe balance is ridiculous. â€

ANKARA (AFP)  â€”   President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is set to return as chairman of Turkeyâ€™s ruling party on Sunday in a special congress, swiftly exploiting a key change agreed in the controversial April referendum on expanding his powers. [Erdogan rejoined the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) on May 2 after the public approved changes to create an executive presidency on April 16.  Under the old constitution, the head of state had to sever ties with their political party and Erdogan left as AKP chairman in August 2014 after his election as president. Rejoining the AKP was the first major change permitted after the vote, allowing the president to be affiliated with a political party almost immediately. Erdogan narrowly won with 51. 4 percent of the vote but most of the new system, including axing the role of premier, will not come into force until November 3, 2019. However, as leader Erdogan can decide the partyâ€™s direction. A woman is suing a casino after a slot machine told her she won a $43 million jackpot, but the casino claimed it was an error and offered her a free steak dinner instead. [Katrina Bookman played the â€œSphinx Slot Machineâ€ at Resorts World Casino in Queens, New York in August 2016 when the screen popped up saying that she won $42, 949, 672. 76, the New York Daily News reported.  Bookman, excited thinking she won a great prize, took a selfie with the screen in the background. When she went to collect her prize, however, a casino worker told her a different story. Alan Ripka, a lawyer for Bookman, said she did not take the casino workerâ€™s offer. Does that mean it wasnâ€™t inspected? Does it mean it wasnâ€™t maintained? ,â€ Ripka told CNN Money. â€œAnd if so, does that mean that people that played there before [Bookman] had zero chance of winning?â€ Ripka is seeking at least $43 million in damages, the amount Bookman claims she won, from the casino for causing his client â€œmental anguishâ€ and setting her back financially as a result of not being able to collect her prize. The complaint says the casino was â€œnegligentâ€ in failing to maintain the machine and names Genting New York LLC, Resorts World Casinoâ€™s parent company, as well as slot machine manufacturer International Game Technology as  . Dan Bank, a Resorts World spokesman, apologized in August and said: â€œCasino personnel were able to determine that the figure displayed on the penny slot was the result of an obvious malfunction  â€”   a fact later confirmed by the New York State Gaming Commission. â€ The New York State Gaming Commission released a statement in August claiming that a disclaimer stating â€œmalfunctions void all pays and playsâ€ was posted on the machine at the time. The Iowa Supreme Court ruled in favor of Isle Casino Hotel in a similar court case in 2015 where the slot machine told a    woman she won $41 million, the Chicago Tribune reported. The court claimed that â€œthe gameâ€™s rules capped jackpots at $10, 000 and didnâ€™t allow bonuses. â€

Meanwhile, heedless to the tectonic changes Trump is forcing, the MSM and the culture still trashes him at every opportunity, even at the risk of descending into total  .  To cite just two of thousands of possible examples, The New Republic headlined one piece on the 20th, â€œWelcome to the Trump Dark Age. â€ And The Wrap, an entertainment publication, offered this    headline, â€œWomenâ€™s March May Outshine Trump Inauguration. â€  Yes, thatâ€™s the ticket.
